annotation.TEXT: When I first played this game, I used to start with Overdrive Ostrich and Morph Moth. Over time however, I switched up my starting point to the standard one that pretty much everyone else takes (Wire Sponge, then Wheel Gator). Thankfully, the X-Hunters provide a chance to take some interesting detours once they start showing up. Even then however, I can tell you right now that Magna Centipede is definitely going to be the last Maverick I'll end up fighting.

It seems like everyone has "their game." The one game you excel at beyond all others you've played, or you know all the in's and out's of it by heart. At one point, Mega Man X2 pretty much fit that category for me. With that being said however, I actually haven't played it for a while now. Given the opportunity (and since I had this game lined up as an eventual playthrough), I figured I should kick off the new year by not only playing a good game, but one that I can properly revisit.

Strike Chain is actually a bit more powerful than you might suspect at first. Aside from having decent damage output, it can also reel you into walls and pick up items. The former trait is actually rather important for the next stage, mainly for trick that lets you get the buster upgrade without having to do any backtracking.

Crystal Hunter is mostly effective against minor enemies, but it has quite the helpful mechanic to it. Enemies hit by it are frozen and can be used as stepping stones, which is actually required to get to certain items. You can also dash into frozen enemies to kill them instantly (in which they'll always drop weapon energy as a result).

This is actually another spot where you can get the Ride Armor to a place that it was originally unintended for. I actually didn't know about this trick until much later on, so I'm not really that good at pulling it off. If you can do this however, it saves quite a bit of time on the mini-boss.

Spin Wheel has strong damage output capabilities, but suffers from a major speed issue. Its start-up time is way too slow, and you can't quick-switch between weapons while the wheel is still active on-screen (and they tend to last a while, too). Honestly, the quickest and most effective way to kill anything with this weapon is to actually get right up in the enemy's face before using it.

Wheel Gator actually has an exploit where you can stun-lock him to death by using the Strike Chain. The timing on it is almost as strict as alternate method of getting the buster upgrade, but it's much easier to get the hang of it once you try it a few times. I know this is essentially cheesing the boss to death, but personally, I'd rather do this than have a potentially 3+ minute fight mostly consisting of waiting for Wheel Gator to surface from the stagnant pool of cherry vodka.

Normally I would do Overdrive Ostrich's stage next...but considering one of the more annoying bosses in the game has now preoccupied himself there, I think it's time to go on one of those slight detours I mentioned before.
For the record: I know it's possible to mash the button to the point where you can fully get the Ride Armor across that gap, but I can never seem to pull it off.

Oh, and this trick can also mess up his AI a bit. I think this mostly has to do with the timing on when you need to hit him (just as he's about to dive below the surface), since the liquid itself also seemed to mess up and produce waves even while he was above it.

With that being said, this maneuver is far from easy to pull off. Even with practice, it doesn't get any less frustrating to properly line this up (the attempt you see here probably had more to do with luck than anything else, to be honest).
